content: always decide to do fewer / more decreases for the toe and increases for the gusset to accommodate your row gauge difference appendix 2 - gauge swatch and choosing sock size 1 once you have decided on the needles / yarn combination for your socks make a gauge swatch in stockinette stitch wash it and block lightly it is always best to make the swatch in the round rather than flat and cast on a sufficient number of sts to ensure accurate measurements make sure that you pick the appropriate needle size for your yarn so that the final fabric is rather dense the tighter your gauge is the more durable your socks will be especially if you are using nylon-free yarn 2 measure st gauge of your swatch per 10 cm / 4 inches - a 3 measure your foot circumference around the ball of your foot and deduct 10% for negative ease - b note on negative ease generally it is advised that your socks made in stockinette should have around 10% negative ease however you can even go down to 15-20 % if you prefer tighter fitting socks larger negative ease might also work better for someone with a smaller arch and very slim calves and ankles 4 number of sts to cast on = foot circumference -10% negative ease in cm or inches x gauge sts / 10 cm or 4 inches = b in cm or inches x a / 10 cm or 4 inches 5 round down the number of sts to the nearest number in the pattern i would advise rounding down to the final number of sts rather than rounding up for a tighter fit of the sock example your gauge swatch is 20 sts per 10 cm / 4 inches and your foot circumference is 23 cm / 9 25 inches 90% of foot circumference = 20 7 cm / 8 3 inches a = 20 b = 20 7 cm or 8 3 inches number of sts to cast on = b cm x a / 10 cm = 20 7 cm x 20 sts / 10 cm = 41 4 sts or number of sts to cast on = b inches x a / 4 inches = 8 3 inches x 20 sts / 4 inches = 41 5 sts round it down to the nearest number in the pattern -
